our tube will reach that intensity which only 
allows the discharge to take place. Thus 
the Leyden jar is the most proper and most 
easy means for shortening the duration of the 
discharge and consequently <s>to<\s> increas<s>e<\s>[ing] the 
temperature of the gas 
12. In several cases, especially if a vapour 
like that of mercury be examined, which 
isolates less, it will be found more conv 
nient, instead of replacing the Leyden jar by a 
larger one, to increase the charge of the 
same jar by intercalating into the circuit 
a spark micrometer, by means of which 
you may add, to the resistance within the 
spectral tube, the resistance of any stratum of air.
13. The leading idea by which one of us was 
guided when he first (1857) directed his at 
tention to spectral Analysis, was to concen 
trate the light in Geissler’s tubes, <s>by<\s> in confining 
the electric current within a capillary channel:
<s>Hence<\s> The construction of our tubes immediately 
<u>derives <\u> follows from it. Accordingly we gave, for <s>[text?]<\s>
different purposes, a different diameter 
to their capillary part. The length of this 
part is of very little influence if the tubes 
are very highly exhausted; we had to shorten 
<s>it<\s> our recent tubes, intended to enclose gases 
and vapours of a greater density, rendered 
Luminous by a powerful induction coil.
13. We employed in our researches the large 
spectral apparatus, constructed by M Sternheil 
Plucker. Spectra der elektrischen 
Luftstromungen 30 Marz 1858
Poggendorff’s Annalen CIV
Plucker. Ueber die Spectra der 
verschiedenen Gase, wenn durch 
dieselben bei starker Verdunnung 
die elektrische Entladung hin-
durchgeht. 25 Aug. 1858. Pogg. Ann.
CV
Plucker. Ueber die Constitution der

denen Gase und Dampfe. 5 Mai
